item.title: Implementing a Simple Caesar Cipher in Haskell
item.description:
Introduction

Today, we’re going to implement a simple Caesar cipher in Haskell. A Caesar cipher is a type of substitution cipher where each letter in the plaintext is replaced by a letter some fixed number of positions down the alphabet. For example, with a shift of 3, ‘A’ would be replaced by ‘D’, ‘B’ would become ‘E’, and so on. This exercise will help you understand basic Haskell syntax, data types, and function definitions.

item.title: Haskell - Implementing a Simple Caesar Cipher
item.description:
Introduction

Today, we’re going to implement a classic cryptographic algorithm: the Caesar cipher. This cipher shifts each letter in a message by a fixed number of positions down the alphabet. While not secure, it provides a great way to learn about character manipulation and basic functional programming concepts in Haskell. We’ll take a plain text message and encrypt it using a key (the shift value), and also be able to decrypt back to the original message.
